snippet: Mitt Romney’s address to the Republican National Convention, as prepared for delivery.

headline.main: Romney’s Speech to the Republican Convention

snippet: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, saying that conditions had improved at two subway stations after their trash cans were removed, implemented the program at eight more stations.
abstract: Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to expand a program that removes trash cans from subway stations in an effort to decrease garbage in the system; agency says the counter-intuitive plan has worked for the most part, forcing riders to take their trash outside the stations; pilot program will be introduced at eight more stations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

headline.main: M.T.A. Expands an Effort to Decrease Subway Trash
headline.print_headline: M.T.A. Expands an Effort To Decrease Subway Trash

snippet: The soldiers are accused of killing a former soldier and his girlfriend, and of plotting to overthrow Fort Stewart, home of the Army’s Third Infantry Division.
abstract: Prosecutors will seek the death penalty against Pvt Isaac Aguigui, Sgt Anthony Peden and Pvt Christopher Salmon, three soldiers from Fort Stewart, Georgia, who are accused of killing fellow soldier Michael Roark and his girlfriend Tiffany York in December 2011; three are also charged with plotting terrorist attacks the base; prosecutors claim the men were members of a small anarchist militia called FEAR, or Forever Enduring Always Ready.

headline.main: Three Georgia Soldiers Face Death Penalty in Killings
headline.print_headline: Death Penalty Sought in Murder Trial of 3 Soldiers

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes what New York still needs to rival Silicon Valley as a technology center, how Zappos may help Pinterest make m...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes what New York still needs to rival Silicon Valley as a technology center, how Zappos may help Pinterest make money and Sheryl Sandberg's book about women in the workplace.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Drone-Tracker App, and Social Media Crime Fighters

snippet: Apple has rejected an iPhone app that puts United States drone strikes on an interactive map because it ran afoul of Apple’s rules on objectionable content.
abstract: Apple has rejected an iPhone app that puts United States drone strikes on an interactive map because it ran afoul of Apple’s rules on objectionable content.

headline.main: Apple Rejects App Tracking Drone Strikes

snippet: In China, smartphones are poised to become even more widespread than they are in the United States. The reason: a host of cheaper phones running on Android.
abstract: In China, smartphones are poised to become even more widespread than they are in the United States. The reason: a host of cheaper phones running on Android.

headline.main: The China-U.S. Smartphone Gap Grows Larger

snippet: If your singing in the shower requires accompaniment, you can use the iShower wireless speaker to bring your Bluetooth music player along.
abstract: If your singing in the shower requires accompaniment, you can use the iShower wireless speaker to bring your Bluetooth music player along.

headline.main: A Music Player for Soapy Singers

snippet: The campaign, with ads beginning to appear this week, is intended to promote The A.P.'s mobile news app, called A.P. Mobile.
abstract: The campaign, with ads beginning to appear this week, is intended to promote The A.P.'s mobile news app, called A.P. Mobile.

headline.main: App From The A.P. Gets Ad Campaign

snippet: Flat-screen TVs, matching linens — nothing is too luxurious for today’s college dorm room.
abstract: Growing number of college students are turning their dorm rooms into plush homes away from homes, spending hundreds of dollars outfitting their rooms with flat-screen TVs and matching linens; many big-box stores, including Target, hold back-to-school sales geared toward this demographic.

headline.main: Leaving Home, but None of Its Comforts
headline.print_headline: Leaving Home, but None of Its Comforts

snippet: A wraparound deck offers spectacular views in every direction at the rooftop bar Soaked at the Mondrian SoHo, and the ambience is like that of Montauk.
abstract: Soaked, rooftop bar at the Mondrian SoHo, offers delicious fruit-infused cocktails and some of the finest views of Manhattan.
